page.title: 01A VILLAGE GROWS. DEFYNNOG
page.content: To the east of the block can be found bronze age standing stones, a Roman road bisects the block and the parish church and Lion pub boast early Norman patronage. Such data may be found in the many and varied local histories. The development of the village became static, even declined, with the coming of the railway in the 1850's. This event saw the development and growth of Sennybridge. The two villages have now almost joined along the main Brecon to Swansea road. However it would be a mistake to confuse the two communities, although both are now greatly Anglicised Defynnog has been able to maintain a core of Welshness that Sennybridge seems to have lost. The major industry of the area is farming, mainly sheep but with some milk, beef, root crops and a little experimentation with cereals.
